title: Gran, 83, explains why she’s glued herself to the floor for Extinction Rebellion
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

A grandmother has glued herself to the street in London today with Extinction Rebellion ‘so that her grandchildren have a planet to live on’.

The protester, 83, who has asked not to be named, told Metro.co.uk about the emotional reason she is fighting for action on climate change.

She said: ‘Extinction Rebellion would like the government to tell the truth, hard though that might be for them.

‘We want carbon emissions reduced to net zero by 2025 and we want the government to sanction a citizen’s charter to advise them on the best way forward.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘I’m 83, I have children and grandchildren, I’m doing this for all children and grandchildren, so they’ve got some planet on which to live.’

She chose her spot outside the Cabinet office in Whitehall, fittingly in front of the Monument to the Women of World War II in central London.

It is one of hundreds of locations the group is targeting during two weeks of disruptive action mirrored in cities across the globe.

The protester – who asked not to be named – has already been arrested for Extinction Rebellion after taking part in a demonstration in Dover last month (Picture: Metro.co.uk)

Watch protesters live near Parliament Square:

The protester was one of ten environmental activists arrested at Dover last month after ‘blockading’ the port.

She said the arrest didn’t put her off glueing herself to the street once again to fight for action on climate change – though admitted her grandchildren have remained at home.

The protester added: ‘I listened to a talk by [Extinction Rebellion] founder Richard Hallam and it put the fear of God into me.

‘There’s so much ignorance and denial and of course vested interests in mass consumerism, political chicanery, the whole usual thing.

‘And doing this, I feel, at least I’m doing something.’

Protesters begin a sit-in on Dean Stanley Street in Westminster, demanding that the government declares a climate emergency (Picture: SWNS)

Extinction Rebellion want the government to sanction a citizen’s charter to advise them on climate change (Picture: Reuters)

Police said 21 people had been arrested by 8am this morning (Picture: EPA)

Protesters claim the demonstration will be ‘five times’ larger than one held in April in which 1,000 arrests were made (Picture: Reuters)

Extinction Rebellion has vowed to ‘shut down Westminster’ as they demand urgent action on the environmental crisis.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Activists say they expect the protests to be as much as five times bigger than those held in April, which shut down major parts of the capital and saw more than 1,100 people arrested.

Drumming, whistles and chanting rang through the streets this morning as protesters attempted to block routes around government buildings in Parliament and Whitehall.

The Metropolitan Police said that by 8am today, 21 people had already been arrested in connection with the protests.

Are you protesting for Extinction Rebellion? Have you been disrupted by the protests? Send your pictures and stories to zoe.drewett@metro.co.uk.
